VSe2/V2C heterocatalyst with built-in electric field for efficient lithium-sulfur batteries: Remedies polysulfide shuttle and conversion kinetics Yanwei Lv Lina Bai Qi Jin Siyu Deng Xinzhi Ma Fengfeng Han Juan Wang Lirong Zhang Lili Wu ⁎ Xitian Zhang ⁎ Key Laboratory for Photonic and Electronic Bandgap Materials, Ministry of Education, School of Physics and Electronic Engineering, Harbin Normal University, Harbin 150025, Heilongjiang, China Key Laboratory for Photonic and Electronic Bandgap Materials Ministry of Education School of Physics and Electronic Engineering Harbin Normal University Harbin Heilongjiang 150025 China Key Laboratory for Photonic and Electronic Bandgap Materials, Ministry of Education, School of Physics and Electronic Engineering, Harbin Normal University, Harbin 150025, Heilongjiang, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract A unique VSe2/V2C heterostructure with local built-in electric field was rationally engineered to remedy polysulfide shuttle and conversion kinetics as a separator modifier for efficient lithium-sulfur batteries. Lithium sulfur (Li-S) battery is a kind of burgeoning energy storage system with high energy density. However, the electrolyte-soluble intermediate lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) undergo notorious shuttle effect, which seriously hinders the commercialization of Li-S batteries. Herein, a unique VSe2/V2C heterostructure with local built-in electric field was rationally engineered from V2C parent via a facile thermal selenization process. It exquisitely synergizes the strong affinity of V2C with the effective electrocatalytic activity of VSe2. More importantly, the local built-in electric field at the heterointerface can sufficiently promote the electron/ion transport ability and eventually boost the conversion kinetics of sulfur species. The Li-S battery equipped with VSe2/V2C-CNTs-PP separator achieved an outstanding initial specific capacity of 1439.1 mA h g−1 with a high capacity retention of 73% after 100 cycles at 0.1 C. More impressively, a wonderful capacity of 571.6 mA h g−1 was effectively maintained after 600 cycles at 2 C with a capacity decay rate of 0.07%. Even under a sulfur loading of 4.8 mg cm−2, areal capacity still can be up to 5.6 mA h cm−2. In-situ Raman tests explicitly illustrate the effectiveness of VSe2/V2C-CNTs modifier in restricting LiPSs shuttle. Combined with density functional theory calculations, the underlying mechanism of VSe2/V2C heterostructure for remedying LiPSs shuttling and conversion kinetics was deciphered. The strategy of constructing VSe2/V2C heterocatalyst in this work proposes a universal protocol to design metal selenide-based separator modifier for Li-S battery. Besides, it opens an efficient avenue for the separator engineering of Li-S batteries. Keywords Li-S battery Shuttle effect Separator modifier VSe2/V2C heterostructure Built-in electric field 1 Introduction Ascribing to the increasingly serious energy crisis and greenhouse effect, rechargeable lithium-ion battery has readily played an indispensable role in the field of energy storage since 1990 [1]. To satisfy the advancing markets for high energy density energy storage devices, lithium-sulfur (Li-S) battery is the very appealing candidate because of its high theoretical energy density of 2567 Wh kg−1, which is about 5 times higher than that of state-of the-art lithium-ion batteries [2,3]. For ideal Li-S batteries, solid S8 is firstly broken and reduced into liquid lithium polysulfides (LiPSs), and then further reduced to solid Li2S2/Li2S in the discharge process [4]. The charging process is reversed. However, Li-S battery still faces the problems of low coulombic efficiency and short life in practical application, which are mainly attributed to the notorious shuttle effect and sluggish redox kinetics of LiPSs [5,6]. Generally, separator engineering is considered as an effective but facile tactic toward mitigating shuttle effect and accelerating redox reactions. In the past decade, diverse multi-functional modifiers have been introduced to separator, including various carbonaceous materials, metal chalcogenides, carbides and nitrides [7,8]. Nonetheless, nonpolar carbonaceous materials are limited in anchoring LiPSs and suppressing the shuttle effect due to their insufficient interaction with polar LiPSs. While the strong adsorption of some polar metal compounds to LiPSs without speeding up their conversion kinetics would boost the accumulation of LiPSs at the cathode side, which dramatically increase the viscosity of electrolyte and therefore hamper the diffusion of Li+ [9]. In this circumstance, scientists have recently switched their focus to the polar materials with excellent catalysis, especially metal selenides. Compared with metal sulfides, metal selenides show similar crystal structure and polarity character, but weaker bonding with metal atoms, far higher conductivity, volume energy density, rate capability and catalytic activity for the sulfur conversion due to their smaller band gaps, 2.5 times density as sulfur and suitable d-electron structures [10,11]. All these unique characteristics manifest that metal selenides should be the good separator modifiers for efficient Li-S batteries. Indeed, several creative studies have reported the successful applications of metal selenides as functional separator modifier in Li-S batteries [12,13]. Consider the unilateralism of single component, ZnSe-CoSe2 [14], C2N@NbSe2 [15] and CoS2-CoSe2 [16] heterostructures have been rationally designed, also. In these heterostructures, metal selenides usually act as catalytic center, and other materials as anchoring site. Nevertheless, the inadequate electron/ion transport ability of those materials has been proved to be a significant deficiency and severely impairs the polysulfide-anchoring-conversion efficiency. Therefore, the design of satisfactory metal selenide-based separator modifier for Li-S battery is still a huge challenge. In recent years, the excellent electroconductivity and unique two-dimensional polar structure of transition metal carbides/carbonitrides (MXene) have endowed them with widespread research interest in energy storage and conversion fields [17,18]. As a representative member of MXene family, V2C has been theoretically predicted to show great superiority to other family members in lithium-ion battery, magnesium-ion battery, and sodium-ion capacitor benefiting from its thinner thickness of single layer and high surface area with more active sites. In our previous works, V2C not only exhibited high electron conductivity and strong adsorption capability for sulfur species by Lewis acid-base affinity, but also presented excellent catalytic ability toward LiPSs conversion [19,20]. The results brightly herald the broad application prospect of V2C in Li-S batteries and its great potential in integrating with metal selenides. Inspired by these results, a unique VSe2/V2C heterostructure was rationally in-situ engineered from V2C sacrificial parent in this work. The VSe2/V2C heterostructure exquisitely synergizes the strong affinity of V2C to LiPSs with the effective electrocatalytic activity of VSe2 on sulfur electrochemistry. Furthermore, the local built-in electric field at the heterointerface can sufficiently promote the electron/ion transport ability and eventually boost the conversion kinetics of sulfur species. As expected, coupling the VSe2/V2C heterostructure with carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and using as separator modifier (denoted by VSe2/V2C-CNTs) can effectively suppress the LiPSs shuttling (Fig. 1 ). The Li-S battery assembled with VSe2/V2C-CNTs modified separator achieved an outstanding initial specific capacity of 1439.1 mA h g−1 with a high capacity retention of 73% after 100 cycles at 0.1 C. Thus, our strategy of in-situ constructing VSe2/V2C heterostructure from V2C sacrificial parent opens an efficient avenue for the separator engineering of Li-S batteries. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of V2C MXene Commercial V2AlC powders (1.0 g) were slowly added to 20 mL hydrochloric acid (HCl) and lithium fluoride (LiF) mixture aqueous solution in a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave, and stirred for 30 min. Later, the autoclave was placed in a water bath and stirred at a constant temperature of 90 °C for 48 h. The precipitates were centrifuged several times with 1 M HCl and deionized water. Finally, dried overnight in a vacuum. 2.2 Preparation of the VSe2/V2C composite The prepared V2C were fully ground with selenium (Se) powders in a mass ratio of 1:2, and transferred the mixture to a porcelain container located in the middle of the quartz tube heating zone in the tubular furnace. Then annealed to 450 °C at 2 °C min−1 in Ar atmosphere and maintained for 3 h. For comparison, using a higher selenized proportion (1:4) and a higher annealing temperature (500 °C) were employed to prepare neat VSe2. 2.3 Preparation of the VSe2/V2C-CNTs separator The VSe2/V2C-CNTs modified separator was prepared by a typical vacuum filtration method. First, we mixed the VSe2/V2C with carbon nanotubes (CNTs) in a mass ratio of 7:3 and ground the mixture for 30 min to yield VSe2/V2C-CNTs. Secondly, VSe2/V2C-CNTs and polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) with a mass ratio of 9:1 was dispersed in a small amount of N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) by ultrasound for 2 h. Finally, the obtained dispersion was vacuum filtered to a commercial polypropylene (Celgard 2400 PP) separator. The VSe2/V2C-CNTs-PP separator was obtained after drying for 2 h under vacuum condition at 60 °C. The V2C-CNTs-PP separator was also prepared through the same procedures and blank separator was labelled as PP. The material was cut into the circular separators with a diameter of 19 mm by the slicer for further experiment (the layer areal surface mass load on the separator is about 0.8 mg cm−2). 2.4 Preparation of the KB/S positive electrode To prepare the KB/S positive electrode, sublimed sulfur (S) and Ketjen black (KB) with a mass ratio of 7:3 were fully ground for 30 min and heated at 155 °C for 12 h using a melt diffusion process. Then, the cooled KB/S composite, Super P and PVDF in a mass ratio of 8:1:1 was placed in a small amount of NMP, the ultrasonic dispersed mixture was coated on aluminum foil and dried overnight in a vacuum at 60 °C before use. The cathodes with sulfur loading of 2.8, 3.7, 4.8 mg cm−2 were also prepared. 2.5 Material characterizations The crystal structures were acquired on X-ray diffraction (XRD, D/max2600 X). Scanning electron microscope (SEM, SU70, Hitachi, Japan) and transmission electron microscope (TEM, FEI, Tecnai TF20) were used to analyze the morphologies, microstructures and elements. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Fisher ESCALAB 250Xi) was adopted to analyze the chemical states of the surface elements. The composition and valence states of the surface elements were analyzed by the affinity between the separators and the electrolyte was determined by contact angle (CA) analysis. The UV–vis spectra were collected in the 250–700 nm spectral range using UV–vis spectrophotometer (Cary 60). 2.6 Assembly of symmetric cells A single electrode was prepared by coating 2 mg of slurry containing different powders (V2C-CNTs or VSe2/V2C-CNTs, slurry preparation method was the same as the positive electrode adding glue) on carbon paper (CP, 13 mm diameter). The symmetric cells were assembled by placing two identical above-mentioned electrodes with bare PP as separator, and 20 μL 0.1 M Li2S6 solution of 1,3-dioxolane (DOL) and 1,2-dimethoxyethane (DME) (1:1, v/v) electrolyte was used as the electrolyte. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) was performed on a multichannel electrochemical workstation (VMP3 Bio Logic, France) with a voltage of −0.8–0.8 V and a scan rate of 50 mV s−1. By sandwiching different separators between two lithium sheets and adding 15 μL ordinary electrolyte (DOL/DME (1:1, v/v) mixed solution containing 1 M bis(trifluoromethane)sulfonimide lithium salt LiTFSI and 2 wt% lithium nitrate LiNO3) to each side, Li||Li symmetric cells were assembled. 2.7 Electrochemical measurements By using 13 mm KB/S cathode, 19 mm bare PP or modified PP separator and blank electrolyte, the model of CR2025 button battery was assembled. In the voltage range of 1.7–2.8 V, the different rates performance of the Galvanostatic charge–discharge were texted (LAND test system). CV and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements were operated with the VMP3 workstation. 3 Results and discussion A schematic procedure for the preparation of VSe2/V2C heterostructure is illustrated in the Fig. 2 (a). First, V2AlC powders with layered MAX phase were chemically etched by LiF/HCl solution via a facile hydrothermal approach. After removing the Al layers, the V2C nanosheets adhered to each other under the van der Waals force, forming a partially delaminated layered structure with an average plate thickness of ∼50 nm (Fig. S1). Subsequently, the well layered V2C and selenium powders were subjected to anneal treatment in Ar atmosphere after grinding. In the thermal selenization process, some VSe2 particles were in-situ bred on the parent V2C, thereby forming VSe2/V2C heterostructure. The XRD spectra of the corresponding products are shown in Fig. 2(b). Notably, the new XRD peaks sprang out after thermal selenization are indexed to the VSe2 crystal structure (JCPDF File NO. 65–3371), consolidating the successful construction of VSe2/V2C heterostructure [21]. To further evaluate the changes in surface chemical state before and after selenium treatment, XPS analysis was conducted (Fig. S2). As shown in Fig. 2(c), the V 2p spectra for the products before and after selenization both consist of three doublets belonging to the oxidation states of V2+, V3+, and V4+. They are located at 513.8/521.3, 515.8/523.0, and 517.0/524.5 eV, respectively. After selenization, the intensity of V2+ and V3+ peaks decrease, while V4+ increases. These changes well illustrate the valence state changes from V2+/V3+ to V4+, corresponding to the successful formation of VSe2. In Fig. 2(d), the C 1s spectrum for pristine V2C can be deconvoluted into four peaks belonging to C–V (282.7 eV), C–C (284.7 eV), C–O (285.7 eV) and O–C=O (287.8 eV), respectively. In sharp contrast, the content of C–V bond obviously decreases after selenium treatment. Meanwhile, the characteristic XPS fingerprints of Se2− 3d 5/2 (53.6 eV) and 3d 3/2 (54.5 eV) can be easily detected in the selenized sample (Fig. S3). The binding energy signals at 55.5 and 56.1 eV are assigned to Se0 3d 5/2 and Se0 3d 3/2, which come from the trace Se powder condensed on VSe2/V2C surface during the preparation process [22]. To explicate the morphology and microstructure evolution induced by thermal selenization, advanced TEM characterization was implemented. Fig. 2(e) shows the TEM image of as-synthesized V2C nanosheets, which look like lithe and diaphanous. The inset is the selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern of those nanosheets. It shows two bright concentric rings consisting of several discontinuous spots. The radii of the two polycrystalline rings can be assigned to the (100) and (110) lattice spacings of V2C. The rectangular areas enclosed in Fig. 2(e) were further characterized by high-resolution TEM (HRTEM). Fig. 2(f) shows the typical cross section HRTEM image of V2C nanosheet, where the (002) interplanar spacing is about 0.96 nm. Fig. 2(g) shows the HRTEM image of V2C nanosheet projected along [001] zone. It reveals a lattice distance of 0.24 nm, corresponding to the (100) interplanar spacing of V2C. After thermal selenium treatment, some particles can be explicitly observed on the V2C nanosheet in Fig. 2(h). The corresponding SAED pattern presents the (011)/(012) diffraction spots of VSe2, besides the (100)/(110) spots of V2C. The HRTEM and inverse fast Fourier transform (IFFT) images of the heterostructure are exhibited in Fig. 2(i). The lattice spacing of 0.26 nm in the red frame belongs to the (011) crystal plane of VSe2, and the one of 0.25 nm in the orange frame represents the (100) crystal plane of V2C. These results domineeringly reconfirm the successful construction of VSe2/V2C heterostructure. The bonus of forming VSe2/V2C heterostructure was elucidated by Mott-Schottky analysis (Fig. S4). The two Mott-Schottky curves exhibit both a positive slope, indicating the same n-type semiconductor nature of V2C and VSe2 [23]. Their flat band potentials (E bf) are −0.49 and −0.09 eV versus Ag/AgCl, respectively. In Fig. S5, their band gaps were estimated to be 1.53 and 1.48 eV by the Tauc plots evolved from ultraviolet–visible spectroscopy. From these analysis, the energy band structures of V2C and VSe2 before and after contact can be sketched out based on Eq. S1 (Fig. 3 a). The different intrinsic Fermi levels of V2C and VSe2 are the driving force for interface electron transfer. Once they are in contact, interfacial electrons are driven to transport from the higher Fermi level of V2C to the lower one of VSe2 until the two reach an equilibrium. Simultaneously, the electron depletion region forms on the V2C side and so does the hole depletion region on the VSe2 side [24]. Such an electron redistribution is explicitly illustrated by the difference charge density of VSe2/V2C heterostructure (Fig. 3b and c). The electron-rich layer around Se atoms (yellow) and electron-depleted layer around V atoms (blue) at the heterointerface agree well with (i) the electron transfer behavior from V2C to VSe2; (ii) resultant built-in electric field pointing toward VSe2 from V2C. At the heterointerface, the small distance of 1.8 Å between the V and Se atoms suggests the strong interfacial interactions between them, which is even stronger than that between the V and Se atoms in VSe2 [25]. The formation of built-in electric field at the heterointerface is highly beneficial for anchoring LiPSs (Fig. S6) [26,27]. The electron density state of VSe2/V2C heterostructure is shown in Fig. 3(d). At Fermi level, it is dominated by the p-orbital of Se atoms and d-orbital of V atoms. In details, the electron density state of d-orbital near the Fermi level is mainly contributed by the V atoms in V2C (Fig. 3e). To assess the effect of VSe2/V2C heterostructure on LiPSs shuttle and conversion reaction, it was coupled with carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and then used as separator modifier (denoted by VSe2/V2C-CNTs) with a uniform thickness about 15 μm (Fig. S7). Elemental mapping analysis of the VSe2/V2C-CNTs modified layer illustrates the homogeneous distributions of C, V and Se elements (Fig. S8). Electrolyte wetting properties of the modified layer was investigated by contact angle (CA) measurements [28]. In Fig. S9, VSe2/V2C-CNTs modified separator presents an obvious smaller contact angle (12°) than that (40°) of bare PP separator, indicating the prior hydrophilicity of VSe2/V2C-CNTs modified separator to commercial PP separator. It benefits the penetration and preservation of electrolyte containing Li+, therefore preferring to realize fast lithium ions migration and prolong the cycle life of Li-S batteries [29]. The Li-S battery performance was evaluated in coin cells (Battery type is shown in Fig. S10a). Fig. 4 (a) shows the CV curves of the cells with different separators. For the cell with bare PP separator, two catholic peaks around 2.2 V (Peak C1) and 1.9 V (Peak C2) in the discharge process are corresponded to the reduction from S8 to long-chain LiPSs (Li2S n (4 ≤ n ≤ 8)) and then to final Li2S2/Li2S. In the charge process, the two overlapped anodic peaks (A1 and A2) at 2.4–2.5 V involve the reverse conversion from Li2S2/Li2S to LiPSs and then to S8. The peak fitting details are shown in Fig. S11. For the cells with different modified separator, the redox peaks show different current intensity. Besides, all the cathodic peak positions shift positively, and the anodic ones shift negatively. The larger the location discrepancy, the larger the polarization. By comparison, the largest peak intensity and smallest polarization of VSe2/V2C-CNTs cell illustrate its superior electrocatalytic activity and fast redox kinetics [30]. Fig. 4(b–d) show the Tafel plots obtained from peak C1, C2, and A1, respectively. During the whole conversion of various sulfur species, the VSe2/V2C-CNTs cell always exhibits the smallest Tafel slope, further verifying the excellent electrocatalytic activity of VSe2/V2C-CNTs. Activation energy (E a) has been extrapolated from the corresponding Tafel slope [31,32]. As shown in Fig. 4(e and f), the E a values of VSe2/V2C-CNTs cell for the conversion from S8 to Li2S n (46 kJ mol−1) and Li2S n to Li2S (15 kJ mol−1) are both less than those of the PP cell. The E a decrement for the whole inverse process is up to 192 kJ mol−1. These results well consolidate the accelerated redox kinetics of VSe2/V2C-CNTs cell. The diffusion properties of lithium ions can be estimated based on the CV curves at various scanning rates (Fig. 4g and h) and Randles-Sevcik equation (Eq. S2) [33,34]. In Fig. 4(i–k), the fitting lines for VSe2/V2C-CNTs cell exhibit higher slope than V2C-CNTs cell, indicating the faster diffusion rate of lithium ions (D Li+) induced by VSe2/V2C heterostructure. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) results were further collected (Fig. 4l). The smaller diameter of the semicircle in the high frequency region for VSe2/V2C-CNTs cell manifests its prior charge transfer characteristics to the bare PP and V2C-CNTs cells. It is worth noting that there are some stunted but conspicuous additional peaks appeared in the panel IV of Fig. 4(a), which could be attributed to the Li-ion intercalation/de-intercalation behavior in VSe2 [35]. To verify this speculation, VSe2/V2C-CNTs||Li cell was assembled with common Li-S electrolyte (batterty type is shown in Fig. S10b). Fig. 5 (a) shows the CV curve performing at 1.7–2.8 V, comparing with the V2C-CNTs||Li cell and CP||Li cell. Interestingly, the CV curve of VSe2/V2C-CNTs||Li cell delivers a series of redox peaks, while the one of V2C-CNTs||Li cell only shows extremely low current response without any redox peak. These phenomena appropriately proves the origin of those redox peaks from VSe2 [36]. To decipher the crystal structural changes of VSe2 during the redox process, in-situ XRD tests were carried out on the cells (Fig. 5b). At the initial discharge stage, the (011) peak of VSe2 from the VSe2/V2C-CNTs electrode is located at 34.2°. It gradually shifts to 32.1°, when the cell is discharged from open circuit voltage (OCV) to 1.70 V. It is corresponding to the interplanar spacing changes from 0.26 to 0.28 nm, which has been attributed to the lithium intercalation reactions [37]. The formation of Li x VSe2 phase provides extra capacity via (xLi + xe− + VSe2 → Li x VSe2), which can be evaluated to be 60 mA h g−1 (Fig. S12) [36]. During the charging process, the (011) peak gradually shift back to 34.2°, corresponding to the transformation from Li x VSe2 to VSe2, indicating a reversible intercalation/de-intercalation process of Li-ion (Fig. 5c) [38]. Fig. 6 (a) shows the cycling performance of the cells with different modifier at 0.1 C. The initial specific capacity of VSe2/V2C-CNTs-PP cell was 1439.1 mA h g−1, much higher than that of V2C-CNTs-PP (1279.1 mA h g−1) and bare PP (942.2 mA h g−1) cells. After 100 cycles, a high capacity retention of 73% was maintained by VSe2/V2C-CNTs-PP cell, which is also better than the V2C-CNTs-PP and bare PP cells. For the case at 0.5 C, the specific capacity of 927.9 mA h g−1 was well maintained after 200 cycles (Fig. S13). In Fig. 6(b), all the GCD profiles for the cells with different modifier exhibit two well-defined discharge plateaus. The boxed areas are further magnified and shown in Fig. 6(c and d). The VSe2/V2C-CNTs-PP cell delivers smaller Li2S activation barrier and overpotential (2.22 V/7 mV) than both V2C-CNTs-PP (2.24 V/14 mV) and bare PP (2.25 V/27 mV) cells, indicating the highest catalytic ability of VSe2/V2C-CNTs toward Li2S oxidation and LiPSs reduction [39]. The polarization potential gap (ΔE) between the charge and discharge plateaus is illustrated in Fig. 6(e). As expected, the VSe2/V2C-CNTs-PP cell shows the smallest one (137.4 mV) among the three tested cells. In addition, the discharge specific capacities for high voltage plateau (Q H) and low voltage plateau (Q L) can be extracted from Fig. 6(b). The Q L/Q H value is a prominent symptom of catalytic activity of catalysts for LiPSs conversion reaction. Notably, the Q L/Q H for VSe2/V2C-CNTs-PP is 2.69, which outperforms that of 2.57 for V2C-CNTs-PP and 2.22 for pristine PP, reaffirming the rapid sulfur species conversion kinetics in VSe2/V2C-CNTs-PP battery (Fig. 6e). Fig. 6(f) shows the rate performance of the cells with different separators. The VSe2/V2C-CNTs-PP cell achieves the best electrochemical performance with high initial specific capacity of 1365, 1205, 1089, 997, 932 and 849 mA h g−1 at different rates ranging from 0.2 to 5 C, respectively. When the current density is suddenly restored to 0.2 C, the VSe2/V2C-CNTs-PP cell recovers a high reversible capacity of 1244.3 mA h g−1, confirming its excellent rate ability. Fig. S14 shows the GCD curves of the VSe2/V2C-CNTs-PP cell at different rates. It obviously shows the two distinct discharge plateaus at each current rate, indicating the effective ability of VSe2/V2C-CNTs-PP separator in mitigating shuttle effect and accelerating redox reactions. In Fig. 6(g), the high reversible capacity of 1001.3 mA h g−1 after 600 cycles at 2 C with a capacity decay of 0.07% per cycle further confirms the above inference. To meet the advanced energy density demands for Li-S batteries in practical applications, VSe2/V2C-CNTs-PP separator was also equipped in the Li-S batteries with high sulfur loading. In Fig. 6(h), the VSe2/V2C-CNTs-PP cells with the sulfur loadings of 2.8, 3.7, and 4.8 mg cm−2 can accomplish a decent rate capacity of 3.7, 4.4, and 5.3 mA h cm−2 at 0.5 C, respectively. At 0.1 C, the VSe2/V2C-CNTs-PP cell with sulfur loading of 4.8 mg cm−2 delivers a high capacity of 5.1 mA h cm−2 after 60 cycles (Fig. 6i). The cell with a thinner lithium tablet (50 μm) and lower E/S ratio of 4.7 μL mg−1 still delivers a discharge capacity of 3.9 mA h cm−2 for the first cycle and keeps nearly the same after 10 cycles at 0.1 C (Fig. S15). These results are the forceful proof for the excellent capability of VSe2/V2C-CNTs in stabilizing the cycle performance of high sulfur loading Li-S batteries. Compared to other separator modifiers reported over the past three years, VSe2/V2C-CNTs shows overwhelming competitiveness taking sulfur loading, cycle retention, initial capacity, etc. into account (Fig. 6j) [40–45]. To further demonstrate the practicality of VSe2/V2C-CNTs-PP separator, VSe2/V2C-CNTs-PP pouch cell with high-sulfur loading of 6 mg cm−2 was assembled as the structure diagram in Fig. 6(k). The GCD curves of the pouch cell deliver the two typical platforms just like the corresponding coin cell (Fig. 6l). As shown in Fig. 6(m), the OCV value of the pouch cell is 3.1 V. It can handily lighten up the light emitting diode array with “HNU” letters or driven mini fan, further verifying the possible practical application of VSe2/V2C-CNTs-PP separator in Li-S batteries. To probe the underlying mechanism responsible for the enhanced Li-S battery performances by constructing VSe2/V2C-CNTs modifier, some pivotal factors such as the adsorption capacity to LiPSs and electrocatalytic effect on sulfur electrochemistry were systematically discussed. Fig. 7 (a) shows the visual adsorption effect to Li2S6. After 6 h, the Li2S6 solution with pristine V2C is almost discolored, indicating its strongest absorbability to LiPSs among the three samples. The solution with single component VSe2 has almost the same color as bare Li2S6 solution, which witnesses its helplessness in LiPSs anchoring. Compared with them, the pale yellow color of the Li2S6 solution containing VSe2/V2C accounts for the medium trapping capability of heterostructure. These intuitive results are further verified by UV–vis spectra. In Fig. 7(b), the intensity of LiPSs absorbance peaks follows the trend: V2C > VSe2/V2C > VSe2. The trapping ability of V2C and VSe2 to LiPSs was evaluated by calculating the adsorption energy between them with Li2S6. The adsorption energy of Li2S6 on the surface of V2C is –22.123 eV (Fig. 7c). According to the Sabatier principle, it is so strong that might lead to the decomposition and dissolution into the electrolyte of LiPSs [46,47]. In sharp contrast, the adsorption energy of Li2S6 on the surface of VSe2 is only –1.359 eV (Fig. 7d), which can well balance the high adsorption energies of V2C when VSe2/V2C heterostructure forms. In this regard, the in-situ grown of VSe2 particles on V2C might invalidate partial adsorption active sites on the surface of V2C nanosheets and eventually lead to the moderate adsorption capacity of VSe2/V2C heterostructure to LiPSs [48,49]. On the other hand, the adsorption energy of Li2S6 on the surfaces of V2C and VSe2 are both higher than the counterparts for the basic ingredients of electrolyte, DOL (–0.824 eV) and DME (–0.843 eV), indicating that the soluble LiPSs are more likely to be adsorbed on the surfaces of V2C and VSe2 rather than dissolved in the electrolyte (Fig. 7e). These results are consistent with the observation of the adsorption tests. Fig. 7(f and g) vividly illustrate the electron density difference of the adsorption of Li2S6 on VSe2 and V2C. For V2C-Li2S6, the charge density between the V and S atom increases with a bader charge value of 3.52 e, indicating the formation of V–S bond due to the strong adsorption capacity of V2C to Li2S6 (Fig. 7h and i). In contrast, the charge density between Li and S atoms decreases in Li2S6, suggesting that Li–S bonds are weakened in LiPSs. For VSe2-Li2S6, similar charge transfer occurs between Li and Se atoms with an ultrasmall bader charge value of 0.20 e, indicating the weak Li–Se bond and adsorption capacity of VSe2 to Li2S6 (Fig. 7h). To access the electrocatalytic effect on LiPSs conversion, the CV curves of Li2S6 symmetric cells with modified carbon paper electrodes (Fig. S10c) were firstly tested. In Fig. S16, the higher current response of V2C-CNTs and VSe2-CNTs cells than the bare CP cell manifests that both V2C and VSe2 have a positive impact on the conversion kinetics of sulfur species. Besides that, the highest current response of VSe2/V2C-CNTs cell straightforwardly reflects the superiority of VSe2/V2C heterostructure over single V2C or VSe2. Fig. 8 (a–c) show the potentiostatic discharge curves tested at 2.05 V with Li2S8 solution as the electrolyte. Of note, VSe2/V2C-CNTs exhibits an earlier nucleation (1888 s) and higher capacity (437.6 mA h g−1) than V2C-CNTs (3264 s, 391.2 mA h g−1) and PP (3965 s, 242.5 mA h g−1). It indicates the superior catalytic effect of VSe2/V2C-CNTs on triggering the fast nucleation and growth of Li2S. Furthermore, VSe2/V2C-CNTs modifier also exhibits superiority in uniformizing the reversible stripping and plating behavior of lithium anode. In Fig. 8(d), the voltage profile of Li||Li symmetric cell with VSe2/V2C-CNTs modifier (Fig. S10e) demonstrates a more stable Li plating/stripping behavior than the cells with V2C-CNTs modifier and bare PP separator. It is mainly due to: (i) the plentiful VSe2/V2C heterointerface with oriented built-in electric field, which endows the heterointerface with lithiophilic nature; (ii) lithiophilic sites provided by VSe2 due to its adsorption capacity to LiPSs via forming Li–Se bond. The almost unchanged intensity and shape of the magnifying voltage–time curves after different cycles illustrate the stable polarization state of VSe2/V2C-CNTs modifier [50]. The superiority of VSe2/V2C-CNTs modifier in uniformizing the reversible stripping and plating behavior of lithium anode can be further verified by Fig. S17. The Li sheet equipped with VSe2/V2C-CNTs-PP separator exhibits shiny silver color and uniform morphology of deposited Li after cycling 300 h, which is in sharp contrast to the Li sheet equipped with bare PP separator. Fig. 8(c) demonstrates the self-discharge behavior of the full Li-S batteries with different separators. After 72 h resting, the capacity attenuation rate of VSe2/V2C-CNTs cell is only 4.9%, much lower than that of V2C-CNTs (8.8%) and PP (32.5%) cells. In Fig. S18, the shuttle coefficient K s of LiPSs is calculated to be 2.64 × 10−3 h−1 for VSe2/V2C-CNTs based on the discharge capacity data of high platform [51]. It is dramatically lower than that of V2C-CNTs (9.62 × 10−3 h−1) and bare PP (20.74 × 10−3 h−1). These results indirectly prove the effective LiPSs shuttle inhibition of VSe2/V2C-CNTs in view of the fact that rapid self-discharge always occurs due to the LiPSs shuttling and their reactions with Li anode [52,53]. The effectiveness of VSe2/V2C heterostructure on LiPSs shuttle was further validated by in-situ Raman characterization. In Fig. 9 (a), the fingerprint signals at 150, 219, and 478 cm−1 of S8 2− are detected on bare PP separator at the beginning of discharge process, and then gradually disappear with the signals of S6 2−/S4 2− (400 cm−1) and S4 2−/S3 2− (455 cm−1) rising up slowly. During the charge progress, the S6 2−/S4 2− and S4 2−/S3 2− peaks just slightly decrease, indicating serious shuttle effect and irreversible loss of LiPSs [54,55]. In striking contrast, LiPSs peaks are almost absent in the spectra of the VSe2/V2C-CNTs-PP separator throughout the entire charge/discharge process (Fig. 9b), which explicitly illustrates the superiority of VSe2/V2C-CNTs in preventing LiPSs crossing the separator during cycling. This superiority can be attributed to the exquisite synergy of the strong affinity of V2C to LiPSs with the effective electrocatalytic activity of VSe2 on sulfur electrochemistry (Fig. 9c). Furthermore, the local built-in electric field at the heterointerface can chemically anchor negatively charged LiPSs on the positively charged V2C side. Meanwhile, the negatively charged VSe2 side accelerates the Li+ diffusion and forms Li–Se, which might facilitate the dissociation of Li–S bonds during LiPSs conversion process and decrease the Li2S nucleation energy barrier, eventually boosting the conversion kinetics of sulfur species. In brief, on the one hand VSe2/V2C-CNTs modifier anchors LiPSs within the cathode side via physical blocking and chemical confinement, and on the other hand VSe2 and local built-in electric field play an important role in reducing the accumulation of polysulfides in the electrolyte via promoting conversion kinetics. 4 Conclusions In summary, rationally designed VSe2/V2C heterostructure was in-situ engineered from V2C sacrificial parent. The strong affinity of V2C to LiPSs exquisitely synergizes with the effective electrocatalytic activity of VSe2 on sulfur electrochemistry, leading LiPSs adsorption and conversion catalysis to be achieved simultaneously. More importantly, the local built-in electric field at VSe2/V2C heterointerface sufficiently promotes the electron/ion transport ability and eventually boost the conversion kinetics of sulfur species. Benefiting from these advantages, an outstanding initial specific capacity of 1439.1 mA hg−1 was achieved by the Li-S battery assembled with VSe2/V2C-CNTs-PP separator with a high capacity retention of 73% after 100 cycles at 0.1 C. More impressively, a wonderful capacity of 571.6 mA h g−1 was effectively maintained after 600 cycles at 2 C with a capacity decay rate of 0.07%. Even with a sulfur loading of 4.8 mg cm−2, areal capacity was still up to 5.6 mA h cm−2. Combined with density functional theory calculations, the underlying mechanism of VSe2/V2C heterostructure for suppressing LiPSs shuttle was deciphered based on in-situ XRD and Raman spectra analysis. This study opens an efficient avenue for the separator engineering of Li-S batteries. coredata.dc:description: Lithium sulfur (Li-S) battery is a kind of burgeoning energy storage system with high energy density. However, the electrolyte-soluble intermediate lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) undergo notorious shuttle effect, which seriously hinders the commercialization of Li-S batteries. Herein, a unique VSe2/V2C heterostructure with local built-in electric field was rationally engineered from V2C parent via a facile thermal selenization process. It exquisitely synergizes the strong affinity of V2C with the effective electrocatalytic activity of VSe2. More importantly, the local built-in electric field at the heterointerface can sufficiently promote the electron/ion transport ability and eventually boost the conversion kinetics of sulfur species. The Li-S battery equipped with VSe2/V2C-CNTs-PP separator achieved an outstanding initial specific capacity of 1439.1 mA h g−1 with a high capacity retention of 73% after 100 cycles at 0.1 C. More impressively, a wonderful capacity of 571.6 mA h g−1 was effectively maintained after 600 cycles at 2 C with a capacity decay rate of 0.07%. Even under a sulfur loading of 4.8 mg cm−2, areal capacity still can be up to 5.6 mA h cm−2. In-situ Raman tests explicitly illustrate the effectiveness of VSe2/V2C-CNTs modifier in restricting LiPSs shuttle. Combined with density functional theory calculations, the underlying mechanism of VSe2/V2C heterostructure for remedying LiPSs shuttling and conversion kinetics was deciphered. The strategy of constructing VSe2/V2C heterocatalyst in this work proposes a universal protocol to design metal selenide-based separator modifier for Li-S battery. Besides, it opens an efficient avenue for the separator engineering of Li-S batteries.
